Melanie Manion, Bjorn Alpermann, and John Kennedy all seem to believe a more positive correlation exists between elections and governance than O’Brien and Han do (Manion, 2009; Alpermann, 2009; Kennedy, 2009).
For a review of the literature that can be categorized as characteristic of the empowerment school, see O’Brien and Han, 2009: 367–68, with notes 48–56; and Hu, 2008: 612–13, with notes 3–9.

In the English literature, Zongze Hu examines villagers’ views on elections and democratic supervision in a northern village. Although the 2003 election was “pretty free and fair, at least quite competitive,” and the popularly elected “democratic supervisory small group” was effective, Hu found most villagers were either indifferent or negative toward direct elections and the supervisory group (Hu, 2008). My study of a village near Beijing found that progress had been made in the three elections from 2001 to 2007 while not much improvement had been made in governance (Yao, 2009). To situate these articles in the theoretical debate on village elections, Hu’s belongs to the disempowerment school while mine supports O’Brien and Han’s conclusions.
For details on this topic, see Yao, 2009.

I stayed altogether eighteen days in my five trips from 2005 to 2008 and interviewed more than 40 people, including the old Party secretary, the old village director, all the members of the first elected leadership and those of the non-governing elite who agreed to be interviewed. Most of the interviewees were men who were over 45 years old and were interested in village affairs. Among these, I had formal interviews with sixteen people, including two women; I had more than one session with nine interviewees. I also had numerous phone conversations with four informants of different factions in the village for clarity and up-to-date information.

XM told me how he had taken advantage of the loopholes in the management of a state-owned construction company in collaboration with its production-and-materials coordinator. The coordinator would put in the books an amount of cement that XM did not in fact deliver. Then XM would sell it on the market and share the income with the coordinator. The illegal ways that XM and Tiger, who will appear later, got rich tell us about the complex composition of rural entrepreneurs, who almost always get positive media coverage. In another of my studies, an entrepreneur of a village near Shijiazhuang who became a popular elected village director also got rich through illegal means. See “Village Elections and the Rise of Capitalist Entrepreneurs” in Journal of Contemporary China (March, 2012).

I observed one of XM’s campaign workers—a village tough—make phone calls to seek votes with both blandishments (“Let’s have a couple of drinks after the election”) and threats (“If you dare not to vote for my No. 3 elder brother, I won’t put up with it”). Of course, it is hard to say how effective this kind of crude campaigning might be.

The retired Party branch secretary learned about the deal from his nephew, a village tough and a beneficiary of the deal. According to him, the sum total to be paid to the construction team specified in the contract was 2.53 million. In addition, two leaders promised to pay the village toughs 100,000 yuan for doing small jobs such as digging ditches. They intended to keep the rest, in the amount of 80,000 yuan. This kind of financial corruption was common among village leaders in handling large construction projects.

When I asked a seemingly capable and principled man serving as the first elected leader of the Villagers’ Financial Supervision Group why he didn’t run for office, his answer was meaningful: “I won’t do it because: one, I don’t have money [referring to the village’s empty treasury], two, I don’t have connections [referring to the support of the township government], three, I don’t know martial arts [referring to the ability to defend himself against village toughs].” Villagers told me stories about how toughs hurt people, even cadres known for being strong characters, and destroyed their property in this and other villages nearby.

Yu Jianrong and He Qinglian have studied the more serious problem of rural “dark and evil forces” (hei’er shili), although the demarcation between them and village toughs is not always clear cut and their differences often seem to be a matter of degree rather than of quality. As “dark and evil forces” can be more harmful and destructive to the social order, they can more easily become the target of law enforcement. The village toughs and predatory entrepreneurs in West Village are more akin to the hunhun’r that Chen studies, whom he aptly categorizes as “a gray force.” See also Yu, 2004; and He, 2004.

In his study of vote buying in eight villages in Zhejiang province and based on the studies of other scholars, Wu Sihong concludes that although democratic governing institutions have been established in most villages and are comprehensive in form, they do not function effectively as village cadres can take advantage of various loopholes (Wu, 2010).

It is conceivable that this assembly of 32 members could evolve into a standing body with its own head to effectively represent villagers’ interests and voices. Thus empowered, it could effectively participate in village governance, including decision making, supervision, and management as stipulated in the Organic Law.

Many scholars, including Lianjiang Li and John Kennedy, argue that most villagers, including “rightful resisters,” would make that distinction between local officials and the Party center (Li, 2005: 228, 248; Kennedy, 2009: 391).

The average annual salary for village cadres of 374 villages in a 2004 national survey was 3,300 yuan, including subsides (Kung, Cai, and Sun, 2009: 67). In a village of similar size and better economic circumstances near Shijiazhuang where I did field work in 2006, the salary was 3,600, with an annual bonus of 5,000, for the village director and the Party secretary.

This was similar to what Zongze Hu had found about the mentality of many villagers in a village in Hebei province: “For them, ‘corruptions are inevitable today. Just let those cadres eat meat [i.e., engage in gross embezzlement] so that we can also drink some soup [i.e., gain some modest benefits]’!” (Hu, 2008: 629).

The remarks of O’Brien and Han sound as if those in the empowerment school and those in the disempowerment school are quite evenly distributed: “For every analyst who concludes ‘except in a few localities, elections have little positive impact on preventing rural authorities from abusing power’, another finds that elections have empowered villagers or enhanced accountability” (O’Brien and Han, 2009: 377). As far as I can see, those who argue the empowerment effect today far outnumber their opponents, especially in the English literature. I consider Zongze Hu’s 2008 article and this article of mine as belonging to the latter school, although the causes we found are different: while he traces villagers’ negative views on direct elections largely to their cultural mentality, I attribute it to their experience of the poor governance under the elected leadership (Hu, 2008: 629–31).

Chen Baifeng refers to the rising problem of village toughs in rural China as “the graying of rural society,” which has driven the political, social, and moral order of the village communities to the edge of collapse (Chen, 2008: 209–12).

In the summer of 2010, the Beijing municipal and the reconstituted district (still known by villagers as the “county”) governments worked together to crack down on “evil forces”—village toughs and predatory entrepreneurs—in at least two villages. The crackdown and sentencing process received widespread media coverage in Beijing. The two defendants—brothers coming from a village 10 kilometers south of West Village—were charged with illegally digging sand, which caused serious environmental damage, and the use of violence in village elections and on other occasions and were sentenced to 17 and 8 years, respectively, in prison and fined 2 million each. The crackdown is part of a larger government action and has affected West Village: in October 2010, the illegal sand digging, which had gone on for over a decade and which had severely depleted the village’s property and caused environment damage in the area, finally stopped. This recent development indicates that determined intervention by the state can effectively contain, if not resolve, the problem of village toughs.

bio.p: Yusheng Yao is an associate professor in the History Department of Rollins College. He is currently working on a monograph on Tao Xingzhi and educational radicalism in the Republican era.
